>> Edward Lengel: Good afternoon and thanks
to all of you for braving the

712.text:
weather to come in here to hear me talk. I
got here just in the nick of time driving

717.text:
up
from Charlottesville and coming into 66, which

was a parking lot, but I made it here

725.text:
believed in infrastructure. He was

and transportation and what would he

734.text:
this? That's a question perhaps we should
leave for the end. I am director of the Washington

741.text:
Papers Project as Tom informed you.
I have been working there since 20 years ago,

747.text:
actually, I began at the Washington
Papers, and I was originally a European historian,

754.text:
modern European history, and so I
came for the Washington Papers from a different

759.text:
direction. It was my first job out of
graduate school, so I began to learn about

764.text:
Washington day by day through reading his
correspondence and through learning what he

771.text:
did almost in between the great moments,
kind of getting at him through the details.

777.text:
Because if you read his correspondence,
it's not one explosive dramatic moment after

784.text:
another. It's a lot of deep thought, a lot
of study, a lot of detail in preparation for

792.text:
some of those great moments, and moving in
between and back and forth between the great

797.text:
moments.
So it takes time to get to know him, and being

802.text:
a military historian, too,
which is how I view myself, I tended to think

807.text:
of him as a soldier. We see Washington in
a number of different guises. We'll see him

815.text:
as a president, politician. We'll see him
as a soldier. We'll see him as a family man.

823.text:
We'll see him as a slave holder. And all
of the results of that. But one aspect of

830.text:
Washington that we don't see is Washington,
the businessman. And it really took me a long

837.text:
time to begin to see him through that
prism. I think one of the problems we have

843.text:
with Washington is that we tend to see him
frozen at certain different moments of time.

851.text:
We'll see him standing there almost as he
puts on a different uniform from one moment

855.text:
to the other depending on how he's appearing
in any particular guise and we forget he was

861.text:
a man constantly in movement, constantly in
the process of change.

867.text:
So we at the Washington Papers have collected
approximately -- copies of

872.text:
approximately 140,000 documents. It's a huge
collection. This is correspondence

882.text:
written to Washington and from Washington,
but then there are a whole lot of other

886.text:
documents in there too. There are ledger books
and account books and piles and piles of

895.text:
receipts and reports and farm reports. Some
of them are fascinating documents in

901.text:
Washington's collection. We began with his
correspondence, letters to and from in

907.text:
different series and worked our way through.
We finished everything except the last

914.text:
couple years of his presidency -- actually
the last year is where we are now. We're

918.text:
finishing that up. And the latter years of
the Revolutionary War. We finished

922.text:
everything else. A number of years ago , it was
2009, actually, some folks at our project

930.text:
began to look more closely at these other
records that we had kind of left to the side.

936.text:
All of those ledgers, account books, receipts,
et cetera, et cetera, and when you look

940.text:
at them, they've really not been valued in
the past. Collectors tend to zero in on the

948.text:
correspondence, particularly correspondence
pertaining to great events, and I see all

951.text:
these financial records. Who cares about all
of that?

955.text:
But if you take another look at them and you
zero in and you see the thousands

960.text:
of people who are referenced and the thousands
of commodities that are referenced and

964.text:
all the different ventures that George Washington
was involved in you see a whole

969.text:
different world there.
So we begin to think about publishing them.

976.text:
We had originally thought of
publishing them in a letter press edition,

980.text:
but these things are so complicated that soon
proved impossible. We decided to drop that

986.text:
option. And instead, in 2012, thanks to a
grant from the national historical publications

994.text: and records commission an arm of the National Archives we began a three-year project at

1002.text:
the University of Virginia to transcribe and
publish all of these documents in a free access

1009.text:
digital edition. And we just had a
demonstration of this edition at Mount Vernon

1015.text:
a couple of weeks ago and it floored
everybody. The complexity of the content and

1022.text:
all of these things that you can discover,
and especially exciting is beginning the end

1028.text:
of this summer, again, thanks to the
National Archives, all of these documents,

1034.text:
all of these materials will be freely
available to everybody on the Mount Vernon

1039.text:
website. You can go in, you can study the
documents, you can play around with them.

1045.text:
You can convert currencies, you can see
videos. There's a little map that shows Washington's

1050.text:
movements based on his accounts.
And you can download data based on the different

1055.text:
commodities that he was involved in.
So it's really an exciting tool that will

1060.text:
be valuable for everybody.
So what can these documents show us?

1067.text:
What can they show us about George Washington
that is really different? And

1072.text:
for me I have to admit it was a struggle to
write a book based on Washington's business

1081.text:
dealings, his attitude toward the economy
and his attitude toward business and his

1088.text:
attitude toward money. It was not natural
for me. Being a military historian, not an

1093.text:
economic historian, but I've come to know
Washington very well. It practically shocked

1099.text:
me to learn how much money and economics occupied
his mind from the very beginning of

1108.text:
his life. And we tend -- we look at it through
21st century eyes. We also think, oh,

1117.text:
this is something a little unsavory. He shouldn't
be thinking about money this much,

1121.text:
should he? I mean, if you talk to friends
and they ask you, well, what are you thinking

1129.text:
about? I'm thinking about money. And the tendency
is to think, well, you're a greedy

1135.text:
individual, aren't you?
But, in fact, money for Washington was not

1141.text:
just a personal matter. It was a
matter for family. It was a matter for community.

1150.text:
And ultimately it was a national
matter. What he did with his estate had national

1159.text:
implications, and what the nation did
with the nation's economy had implications

1166.text:
for him, for his family, for his community.
And he really believed that ultimately economics

1176.text:
were the fundamental issue determining
freedom or not freedom. And even morality

1187.text:
or immorality. And prosperity or poverty.
So these thoughts were really fundamental

1198.text:
to him, and in the brief time that I
have available now, I'm going to go through

1203.text:
different stages of his life, look at some
of his own business dealings, look at some

1209.text:
of his attitudes towards the economy based
in

1214.text:
his documents and based in his financial records.
And really to get an understanding of

1222.text:
why this was important to Washington, you
need to even start before George Washington

1227.text:
and look at his family. The first Washington
of George Washington's branch to arrive in

1236.text:
the colonies in North America was John Washington,
his great grandfather, who arrived in

1243.text:
1656. Now, Virginia, at that time was all
about tobacco. Tobacco was the boom crop.

1251.text:
It was the essential commodity of the whole
Virginia economy. Everybody was planting

1258.text:
it. Everybody was growing it. And you would
think there would immediately be a glut on

1263.text:
the market, that tobacco would pass its peak
pretty quickly, but as technologies

1269.text:
improved and labor saving devices improved,
tobacco proved to be quite an enduring crop.

1277.text:
So John Washington came from England. His
intention when he arrived in 1656 was to pick

1283.text:
up some tobacco and take it back to England
and sell it there. He had no intention of

1288.text:
staying in Virginia. Well, his ship sank.
He loaded it up with tobacco and ready to

1294.text:
go
back to Virginia, the storm came in and it

1297.text:
foundered. So John exhibited a couple of the
traits that would pass down through his family.

1305.text:
One was a quick adaptability. He's
faced with a disaster, how is he going to

1310.text:
adapt? The other one is that Washington is
good at marrying the right women. Really good

1317.text:
at that.
So John Washington marries a woman who is

1321.text:
an heiress from the Virginia gentry,
who has quite a substantial inheritance, quite

1328.text:
a substantial dowry, and she's also a
great partner for him. And they get married

1335.text:
and he decides to stay in Virginia and he
builds up his estate. He grows. He purchases

1341.text:
more land. He begins to diversify. He
begins to expand and become a more substantial

1348.text:
planter. He dies young. He's only 38
years old when he dies. That's another unfortunate

1354.text:
family trait. His son, Lawrence,
tries to do the same thing. He dies when he's

1360.text:
46 years old.
Lawrence's second son, Augustine, who was

1365.text:
George Washington's father, is a
fascinating man. We tend to only see him through

1371.text:
the Parson Wing fables, the cherry
tree story when George Washington chops down

1378.text:
the cherry tree supposedly and his father
says, did you chop this down? And George says,

1383.text:
I cannot tell a lie, I chopped down the
cherry tree. We tend to see Augustine as a

1389.text:
very loving and paternal figure who
tragically died when George was only 11 years

1396.text:
old. Augustine was more than that. He
was a very savvy businessman. He, too, expanded

1405.text:
his land holdings dramatically. He
continued to work with tobacco, but he decided

1412.text:
to get into ironwork. There's something
called the Principia ironwork. Somebody discovered

1420.text:
some excellent land for developing
iron foundries. What Augustine did was bought

1426.text:
up all the surrounding land and began to
develop an industry in connection with some

1432.text:
English partners and became very prosperous
through that.

1436.text:
Now, his first wife died young, left him a
son named Lawrence. And Augustine

1444.text:
had to find a woman for his second wife. And
he settled upon -- and, of course, she

1452.text:
settled upon him -- Mary Ball, to become Mary
Ball Washington. And she is one of the

1462.text:
most under-appreciated women in American history.
For a lot of different reasons. And

1468.text:
she's really under-appreciated in George Washington's
life. Her first born son was

1473.text:
George, George Washington born in 1732.
Now, Augustine and Mary Ball were excellent

1483.text:
partners. And one of the things
that Augustine liked about Mary was that she

1488.text:
was a strong woman, she was dedicated. She
was very intelligent, and she knew how to

1495.text:
run an estate. She knew how to manage a
business. When Augustine, as he often had

1502.text:
to do, was running off to different parts
of

1505.text:
Virginia, going overseas to England, working
out various business deals, he had to have

1511.text:
somebody to keep things running, and Mary
did that, at the same time she's raising

1517.text:
several children, as well as Augustine's children
by his first marriage. This was one

1524.text:
tough lady and one very smart lady, and, yeah,
she's come to us -- we tend to see,

1530.text:
because George didn't like her later in his
life, he had problems with her, we think she

1535.text:
must have been bad. She wasn't. She raised
George, particularly after Augustine died

1543.text:
when, like many Washingtons, he died young.
Augustine died when George was only 11

1550.text:
years old. Now, there's been some debate,
would George have gone off to England for

1558.text:
his
schooling like many young men did if Augustine

1562.text:
had not died?
We're not sure, but we know for certain that

1566.text:
once Augustine died there was no
chance of his being sent to England. He had

1570.text:
to stay in Virginia. Nor did Mary feel
they could afford to give him a formal education,

1578.text:
and George would lament that later on
in his life. But what he got from Mary, who

1584.text:
directed his education and from his tutors,
was a very practical education. It was based

1591.text:
on things like geometry, and mathematics,
and accounting, with a little bit of classics,

1599.text:
a little bit of liberal arts on the side,
but her attitude was, George, you need to

1604.text:
learn how to manage this estate. It's going
to come down to you eventually someday. And

1611.text:
you're going to need to grow and you're
going to need to build your estate.

1617.text:
So his education was very practical, but there
were also some fundamental

1622.text:
principles that he got from his mother. They
were things like thrift and diligence and

1632.text:
almost fanatical accounting and record keeping,
which George kind of liked anyway,

1636.text:
because he was a detailed guy. If you look
at early school exercises, he was the type

1641.text:
of guy if you gave him a dictionary or almanac
he would find it immensely fascinating

1647.text:
and would pore over it and learn more about
it. He liked to keep records.

1653.text:
She also taught him an absolute horror of
debt. And I like to say that among

1661.text:
the things that Washington feared and detested
most in his life were Thomas Jefferson

1669.text:
and debt.
Maybe Tom came first. I'm not sure. Especially

1675.text:
later on in his life. But
early on in his life, debt was the main fear.

1681.text:
Now, George, when he's a teenager, he's a
dreamer, he's like a lot of young

1688.text:
men. In his teen years he imagines for a while
his older half brother, Lawrence,

1695.text:
mentors him and sells him on a cockamamie
idea that he's going to do see and George

1703.text:
is
ready to go and bags pack and about to get

1707.text:
on the ship when Mary, thankfully his mother,
puts her fist down and says, no way you're

1713.text:
getting on that ship, you're going to stay
here and tough it out and you're going to

1719.text:
learn.
Shortly afterwards, thanks to his connections

1721.text:
with the Fairfax family -- and
the Fairfax family was the most powerful family

1725.text:
in Virginia at that time, their estate
based at Belvoir. Belvoir is one of the great

1731.text:
houses you just wish had survived. It
burned down later on during George's lifetime,

1739.text:
but it must have been a magnificent,
magnificent place.

1743.text:
George tended to spend a lot of time there
with the Fairfax family. Through

1747.text:
his connections with the Fairfaxes he got
his first job as a surveyor in his teenage

1753.text:
years. For many of us and particularly for
me, their first teenage job is a nightmare

1760.text:
and you don't want to remember it. For George
his first teenage job was a smashing

1765.text:
success. He got the survey for the proprietor,
Lord Fairfax and later for the family in

1772.text:
different parts of Virginia moving out through
the valley and was eventually able to set

1778.text:
up a trade on his own account to earn money
surveying for different land holders in

1783.text:
different places. And the surveying career
taught him a lot. Again, about

1789.text:
fundamentals, basics, how to understand the
land, how to judge the richness of the soil.

1796.text:
Now, land is fundamental to Washington's wealth.
I'm going to get back to that. And to

1802.text:
the national wealth. But to be able to judge
the land, judge the topography, to be able

1808.text:
to measure, to be diligent, and how to earn
money and to save it. And he has a couple

1814.text:
of problems early on. He's an easy touch for
a loan. Particularly with family members

1820.text:
and friends, they'll go after him as soon
as they say, hey, George is earning a lot

1825.text:
of
money, you give me a loan? And then they don't

1827.text:
pay it back. He learned those lessons
early on. Also, he does enjoy gambling. He

1835.text:
does enjoy a throw of the dice. He does
enjoy cards. He does enjoy billiards. I wish

1843.text:
somebody would create a painting of
Washington playing billiards. I would just

1847.text:
love to see that. Or him around a card
table playing poker or something like that.

1854.text:
He doesn't gamble excessively, but he loses
money and learns through hard

1860.text:
lessons elements of self-discipline.
Well, the French and Indian War comes around

1868.text:
in 1754 and I won't get into
detail with the French and Indian War because

1876.text:
it's a bit outside my topic. Suffice to
say that George believes that this is going

1884.text:
to be an opportunity for him to earn some
distinction. You have to put him in the context

1889.text:
of his time. Yes, he was a young man,
22, 23 years old at the beginning of the French

1898.text:
and Indian War, who like many young men
yearn for adventure and he yearns for an opportunity

1903.text:
to achieve glory. But he is a
member of a certain class, a certain social

1909.text:
class, the Virginia Gentry. They are the
closest thing we ever had to a native aristocracy.

1918.text:
The Virginia Gentry are about perception.
They're about how you appear, what

1925.text:
type of figure you put on, what type of honors
have you won, distinctions, offices have

1933.text:
you held.
If you look at some early images of George

1939.text:
Washington, particularly you look
at other images of other members of the gentry

1943.text:
in the mid 18th century. We tend to look
at a portrait by Charles Wilson Peale after

1949.text:
the French and Indian War and, how did this
guy get so fat? Because his belly is sagging

1957.text:
out and a couple buttons are missing.
That was about perception. It doesn't necessarily

1962.text:
mean he put on a lot of weight. It
means that perception of easy living, that

1969.text:
perception of having plenty to eat, of being
relaxed, of living well and living sumptuously

1976.text:
was very important. The French and
Indian War was also about George earning the

1981.text:
street cred so that he could belong to the
Virginia Gentry. He learned some tough lessons

1987.text:
in the French and Indian War. How to
manage men. But the most important lesson

1995.text:
that he learns is fundamentals, details
matter. If you're going to manage any type

2002.text:
of an enterprise, you need to study and
learn the details. He learns one of the very

2009.text:
basic things that he learns, if men aren't
paid, they're not going to fight. We can get

2017.text:
angry about that. We can rant and we can
rave, how dare you! You have a cause to fight

2025.text:
for. You have a goal to fight for. And
you're talking about money? What kind of a

2030.text:
person are you anyway?
George says that's a ridiculous attitude to

2037.text:
take. These men have families.
They have lives. They need to live. That sounds

2047.text:
simple to us. At that time it was not
simple, that any commander needs to understand

2052.text:
those basic facts.
After the French and Indian War is over, George

2060.text:
has come into the estate of
Mount Vernon. He's come into that estate.

2066.text:
It's rather complicated, via his older half
brother Lawrence, who died before the war,

2071.text:
probably of tuberculosis. And when Lawrence
dies and then his widow dies and his young

2078.text:
daughter dies, the estate of Mount Vernon
then comes to George. It's a process that

2084.text:
takes a number of years. George actually
rents the estate for a time before it actually

2089.text:
finally comes fully into his possession.
Now, he also, in 1759, in January, he marries

2098.text:
a woman named Martha Dandridge Custis.
Martha is very much in many ways like George's

2109.text:
mother. He's very much like
other women this the Washington family, in

2116.text:
that, you know, we look at their marriage
and

2120.text:
we say, Martha was the wealthiest widow in
Virginia when George pursued her. And we

2126.text:
think she just kind of stood there supine
and George went up and snatched her and

2131.text:
carried her off. Well, she has a choice to
make too. They chose each other. They

2137.text:
chose each other for a number of reasons.
Yes, I think it's safe to say from George's

2142.text:
perspective she had a vast estate that had
come down to her from her first husband, that

2149.text:
he was able then to not completely claim but
he was able to use to build his estate and

2156.text:
his wealth. But he also saw her as a worthy
partner, as a woman who, like his mother,

2163.text:
was tough-minded, who was a good manager,
and who would be able to be able to manage

2171.text:
the
estate. There's a great collection of documents

2175.text:
after Martha's first husband dies,
Daniel Parke Custis, Martha writes a couple

2183.text:
of letters to the British merchants who had
been managing their trade overseas, and she

2190.text:
says in no uncertain terms, I'm in charge
now, I'm taking this over. You're going to

2195.text:
have to deal with me. So she was that type
of person, and I think from her perspective,

2202.text:
George was a man who knew what he wanted,
who was on the make, so to speak, who wanted

2207.text:
to improve, who wanted to provide for his
heirs. Now, if he had been somebody who was

2213.text:
just motivated by personal wealth and
greed, I think I would have turned her off.

2219.text:
She had children of her own. They would
have children of her own. George was focused

2224.text:
on providing for his heirs, and she knew
he would be a smart, prudent manager, unlike

2230.text:
a lot of other Virginians who ruin their
wealth with carelessness.

2236.text:
So they're married and they return to Mount
Vernon, and Washington in the

2242.text:
early 1760s begins to work on building up
his estate. Now, there are a number of

2247.text:
things that he takes for granted. One is slavery.
I'll return to that in a moment.

2252.text:
Another thing he takes for granted is tobacco.
Tobacco has been everything for

2256.text:
generations. His family has been founded on
tobacco, but he begins to see in this

2261.text:
period that tobacco isn't working anymore.
And there are a number of reasons for it.

2268.text:
One is tobacco really drains the soil. It
ruins the soil quickly. And all you can do,

2274.text:
you know, the simplistic mindset of that time,
clear more land and plant more tobacco

2280.text:
and it sucks the land dry. You clear more
land and plant more tobacco. That's pretty

2286.text:
wasteful. Another thing is that tobacco is
very labor intensive. It takes a lot of

2292.text:
labor to produce. But from George's point
of view, the worst thing is that tobacco ties

2299.text:
him to the British mercantilist credit system.
Now, what this means is that if you're a

2306.text:
planter and you want to sell your tobacco,
you can't just -- there are different

2312.text:
varieties of tobacco by the way, some better
than others, and you can't just develop new

2316.text:
technology and improvise and you can sell
it in different ways, you can find, here is

2320.text:
a
better market, maybe there's a great market

2322.text:
in France, a great demand for tobacco in the
Caribbean. You can't do that. You have to

2328.text:
sell through specially appointed British
agents, who take your tobacco, they ship it

2336.text:
overseas in British ships to Britain and
they sell it where they see fit for whatever

2343.text:
prices they can find. And then what do
they give you, the Virginia planter in return?

2350.text:
They give you credit. Now, what had
happened -- I talked about the Virginia Gentry

2355.text:
being about appearances. This is a
conspicuous consumption culture. The gentry

2361.text:
take this credit and buy luxury goods.
It's not the same as we think, you're buying

2367.text:
manufactured goods in Britain, the things
you need, they by luxury goods. They buy clothes

2373.text:
and fine carriages and all kinds of
bottles and fine things to eat and fine wine

2380.text:
and stuff to drink. It reduces them to
debt.

2386.text:
Dozens of Virginia planters, who were Washington's
friends, are ruined by that

2395.text:
debt. And they have to hold wateries, which
are essentially fire sales to sell off

2400.text:
their holdings and they have nothing. Their
whole careers are over.

2406.text:
Washington makes a quick decision and says,
I can't bear this. He's starting

2410.text:
to fall into debt too. He says, this is not
going to work, and he switches to wheat.

2418.text:
It was like, many things that Washington did,
and in his business ventures as

2423.text:
well, is he -- when he had to make a decision,
he studied it very carefully first, and

2430.text:
that's what he does with this, studies it
very carefully, but when he makes a decision,

2435.text:
I'm going to wheat, that's it. He switches
over almost his entire estate and Martha's

2441.text:
as well to wheat.
Okay, sounds good, right? But there are a

2447.text:
lot of repercussions of this. One,
the most important one, is that now he can

2453.text:
produce and he can sell and he can trade on
his own account for cash through American

2461.text:
merchants throughout North America. He buys
expensive French millstones to construct a

2469.text:
new effective productive gristmill at Mount
Vernon. So he can mill a lot of flour and

2477.text:
he can sell that flour -- it was actually
George Washington brand flour that he sells

2482.text:
through the Caribbean and throughout North
America, but Mount Vernon is transformed within

2489.text:
a couple of years, not just from the
flour but because he is able to move from

2495.text:
a more labor intensive to a less labor
intensive production. Now all the time of

2503.text:
the enslaved people on his estate and the
workers on his estate, instead of just working

2509.text:
in tobacco, they can produce for
themselves. Very soon they're producing and

2515.text:
spinning and weaving and producing their
own clothing and selling that clothing to

2519.text:
other estates, they're cobbling their own
shoes. The blacksmith operation expands dramatically

2526.text:
and all the ironworking going on
there, they can produce and repair their own

2530.text:
tools and equipment and sell them as well.
The Fishery is established and expanded. Millions

2537.text:
of fish coming up the Potomac,
nothing like today, alas, but when George

2543.text:
saw the Potomac River in those days, millions
upon millions of fish teeming through the

2548.text:
river and leaping into the area. He
establishes a Fishery there that feeds his

2554.text:
own people and they can sell abroad. He's
beginning to develop that production.

2562.text:
Very briefly, the lead up to the Revolutionary
War, what Washington sees

2569.text:
here -- and many Americans see -- is that
the British are denying us of our right to

2580.text:
produce our own wealth, to invest our own
money, to establish our own prosperity and

2591.text:
to
become free in that way.

2594.text:
I mentioned earlier -- and I'll touch on this
with slavery too in a moment.

2600.text:
Washington believed morality and industry
were two sides of the coin. This is

2604.text:
fundamental with him. The industrious man
is a moral man by virtue of his industry,

2610.text:
his
work, his hard work, his production. A moral

2615.text:
man will naturally want to work and will
want to produce. If you deny an individual

2625.text:
the ability to work and produce and develop,
you corrupt him. He doesn't see the problem

2635.text:
with slavery right yet, but he will later
on. He's looking at this problem for himself

2641.text:
and fellow white Virginians right now,
that the British credit system and the British

2649.text:
restrictions on westward expansion,
British restrictions on development of American

2654.text:
currency, all of the other restrictions
prevent us from achieving that. And leave

2662.text:
us in a form of bondage. It's that calculus,
that basic calculus that leads him in his

2669.text:
mind to the idea of the need for political
freedom. Political freedom gives us the right

2679.text:
to determine the terms of our own
production and prosperity. What really turns

2685.text:
him against the British are the British
reactions, yes, the Stamp Act, the Townsend

2692.text:
duties, all those upset him very much, but
when the British take punitive measures against

2700.text:
American commerce, closing the Port of
Boston, for example, that's what drives George

2708.text:
into a frenzy, you're trying to drive
down our economic. There's a take-off to use

2717.text:
a modern term, we used take-off as people,
as Americans, we're about to begin to become

2725.text:
a prosperous people who can develop
agriculture and industry, and the British

2730.text:
are holding us back. It's that simple
calculus that determines Washington's ultimate

2739.text:
reaction against British rule.
Now, he believes first and foremost that our

2748.text:
resistance to British rule should
be based on economic warfare. And here I'll

2753.text:
back track just a moment. When you look at
Washington, if you want to understand him

2761.text:
for all of his life after he was in his mid
20s, for the whole remainder of his life,

2768.text:
you have to remember he is a combat veteran.
That's essentially important to his outlook

2776.text:
and to his world view. He has been in
combat, not just as an officer, not just directing

2784.text:
men, but he has personally been in
combat. He's not been wounded. Almost miraculously.

2792.text:
But he is seen, as he wrote about
after the French and Indian War, the cries

2797.text:
of the wounded, the suffering, everything
else. But he also experienced a comradeship.

2802.text:
He experienced those different aspects,
but what it comes down to is he understands

2807.text:
what war is really about. Unlike many
others, you can praise men, and we should,

2817.text:
like Patrick Henry, John Hancock, Thomas
Jefferson, and the others, for the great things

2823.text:
they did. None of them understood
anything about war. They didn't know what

2828.text:
it did. And Washington believed we should
avoid a physical military conflict with the

2836.text:
British almost at all costs. Almost at all
costs, that it should be an economic war to

2844.text:
teach the British that they need to give us
our freedom.

2848.text:
Now, when it turns into a physical military
conflict, he accepts and goes

2854.text:
along with that. But in the war -- and I'll
just talk about the war very briefly before

2862.text:
I move to the presidency, so I can give time
for questions. In the war, as commander in

2869.text:
chief of the continental army, Washington
sees a basic goal, basic aspiration. We're

2882.text:
not just in this to beat the British on the
battlefield. That's not the only reason why

2889.text:
we're here. We're here to create a nation.
And the British begin to make war,

2897.text:
particularly in destroying our towns and destroying
our commerce. That's really what

2901.text:
turns Washington toward the belief we have
to be independent. But then he thinks, okay,

2906.text:
look here, we're creating a government, we're
creating an economy. We're creating an

2911.text:
army and navy and everything else. We're creating
a society. We're trying to build a

2917.text:
nation.
If you defeat the British but you destroy

2923.text:
your country at the same time, what
have you got?

2928.text:
There were those who urged Washington to prolong
the war, who urged him to

2932.text:
engage in a guerilla conflict, a type of down
and dirty vicious no holds barred conflict

2941.text:
that would have absolutely no boundaries to
really punish the British and get them to

2948.text:
leave. Washington says, no, we do that, we
might defeat the British but we'll destroy

2953.text:
ourselves in the process. We must build our
infrastructure and economy while we're

2959.text:
winning this war. That's why he fights a war
that is very principled, that is very

2965.text:
conventional. That's why he refuses to do
things like seizing goods from American

2970.text:
civilians. We've got to build a country here.
And there's another thing from the war that

2977.text:
comes out that I think is
fascinating. I found this phrase. There's

2983.text:
a letter early on in 1776 where Washington
says, "interest is the guiding principal of

2991.text:
humankind."
I originally looked and thought this is a

2997.text:
cynical statement, because he's
saying everybody is in it for themselves.

3002.text:
And the more I looked at it, though, in the
process of writing this book, I saw Washington

3007.text:
sees self-interest is a natural thing.
It's not necessarily good, it's not necessarily

3013.text:
bad, but it's natural. Human beings
look at themselves. They look at their own

3019.text:
selves, families, communities. Think of the
Revolutionary War. Think of the women of America,

3025.text:
if they had decided, this war is no
longer worth fighting. They were the ones

3029.text:
who were experiencing on the ground all of
the aspects of war's suffering and hardship,

3036.text:
you know, with their farms, with their
families, with their communities, and seeing

3042.text:
them suffering. If they decided that we're
going to be ruined, that war would have ended.

3051.text:
No matter what we were doing on the
battlefield, the American people, men and

3055.text:
women, were choosing every moment to continue.
And if you face them with ruin, no matter

3063.text:
how patriotic they are, a lot of people didn't
understand this at the time. They thought

3068.text:
patriotism is everything. If you believe in
the cause, you will overcome. Even if you

3074.text:
starve to death. Even if your children die.
Even if your business is ruined. Even if you're

3082.text:
impoverished. Does that mean you're
not a patriot, if you say, stop, I don't want

3088.text:
my family to be ruined?
That's what self-interest is about. You need

3092.text:
to show people that they can
build and they can grow and there's a purpose

3097.text:
to this. But he also uses this phrase
"community of interest." "Communities of interest."

3103.text:
How do you convince Americans not
to accept British rule? How do you convince

3108.text:
them not to trade with the British? You
trade with them yourself. You maintain a stable

3114.text:
economy. When you establish your
camp -- every camp in Washington's army establishes,

3121.text:
he sets up a market to trade with
the people to maintain that interaction so

3129.text:
that we have a community of interest, a
common interest that we see we're in this

3133.text:
together, it's in all of our interests to
remain unified and to continue the fight.

3140.text:
So the war ends and we can get more to this
in Q&A, but after the war in the

3147.text:
confederation period, Washington sees that
lack of stability. The currency has

3155.text:
collapsed practically during the war. It reaches
a point where you have to pay a few

3159.text:
hundred thousand dollars to buy a horse or
to buy a wagon or anything like that.

3164.text:
Inflation is insane. And after the war, stability
-- the currency is still a mess. We

3170.text:
still have state currencies and still have
a government that can't raise taxes on its

3174.text:
own account, so currencies are very volatile.
Washington tries to develop his own

3180.text:
estate, to build, to adapt new technologies.
He brings scientific farming, the new

3185.text:
husbandry to Mount Vernon and establishes
a lot of new industries, but he sees

3190.text:
instability of economies and also political
instability, and worst of all the potential

3199.text:
for unrest and war. Washington is a man of
peace. And I would keep repeating that if

3212.text:
I
had more time. He is a man of peace. Peace

3216.text:
is essential to prosperity. When he sees
things like Shay's Rebellion in 1786, anti-tax

3226.text:
uprising in Massachusetts, he's terrified.
This will undermine the very foundations of

3233.text:
our freedom. That's why he's passionate
believer. He doesn't think the constitution

3238.text:
is perfect, but he's a passionate believer
in ratification.

3243.text:
As president -- and I will end with this.
To give you a few basic principles

3249.text:
of his goal as president, when he accepts
the presidency in 1789 and he's inaugurated,

3258.text:
he writes "To establish the national prosperity..."
And this is a literal quotation.

3265.text:
"To establish the national prosperity should
be my first, my only aim."

3274.text:
To establish the national prosperity. How
does he do that?

3280.text:
Despite what some people say, he was not Alexander
Hamilton's cipher. He

3284.text:
didn't say, tell me what to do, whatever you
say, I'll go with it.

3290.text:
He gives Hamilton a vision and he gives Jefferson
a vision. He knows that

3295.text:
Jefferson and Hamilton hate each other from
the very beginning. He says, okay, that's

3299.text:
all right. This happens. We want men of genius
in government, who have, yes, very

3306.text:
fundamental basic differences in their outlook
currency but they have the same goal to

3312.text:
create a great nation. You can build off that
tension and that energy between Hamilton

3319.text:
and Jefferson and the others and you can build
from that. It absolutely dev states him

3326.text:
when later on the two of them tear the country
apart and tear politics into faction.

3332.text:
But he believes with Hamilton, establish a
vision. The vision is stability.

3339.text:
Stable currency, stable economy. The government
should be able to tax but why does the

3344.text:
government tax? The government brings taxes
in to maintain domestic peace, to maintain

3352.text:
international peace, and to create a level
playing field at home, so that Americans can

3362.text:
produce their own wealth. Sound simplistic?
That's what he believed. That people

3369.text:
produce the wealth. The government's role
is to -- yes, it needs taxes, it needs to

3374.text:
be
stable, it needs to be strong, but its goal

3379.text:
with the people and prosperity create
stability, create a situation where capital

3386.text:
is readily available and people can invest
and they can grow. And he's successful in

3391.text:
that.
Now, let me say one thing about slavery and

3394.text:
then I'll finish up and we'll have
time for questions. Washington turns against

3399.text:
slavery and really in the 1770s,
1780s. Now, I'm not going to excuse the fact

3407.text:
that he was a slaveholder. The truly
great people, the truly great people don't

3415.text:
just reflect their times. They transcend
their times. And in many ways Washington did,

3419.text:
but with slavery he did not, at first.
He didn't recognize the moral evil of slavery

3426.text:
right away, but what turned him
against slavery ultimately was that principle

3432.text:
of, you're telling these people they have
to work or they'll be punished. Does that

3440.text:
give them any motivation? No. It corrupts
them. It corrupts those who force them in

3447.text:
the system and ultimately it's an economic
dead end. By the 1790s he believed that slavery

3453.text:
would bring us down to stagnation and
destruction. Economically. And so that's why

3461.text:
in his will he mandated that his slaves
should be freed after Martha's death. She

3467.text:
didn't like that too much, so she freed them
right away.

3471.text:
But I think in Washington's vision, his sense
as a business person, his

3476.text:
understanding of money, really was the foundation
of our national prosperity. So thank

3481.text:
you very much. I'll end with that, and I'm
happy to take questions.

3487.text:
[Applause]
>> Edward Lengel: Go to the microphone, please.

>> Greetings. So could you say a little more
about slavery, how much of

3507.text:
Washington's wealth was in slavery and how
essential was it to his success and was it

3513.text:
realistic if the slaves were all gone that
his estate could prosper?

3517.text:
>> Edward Lengel: So you have to realize that
the enslaved people on his

3524.text:
estate ultimately created his wealth. These
were the men and the women and children who

3529.text:
worked and who produced and who grew for him,
and we neglect that reality, you know, at

3537.text:
our peril. And it would be wrong to neglect
that. He held ultimately -- I can't

3543.text:
remember the figure off the top of my head.
A few hundred slaves. Many of them were

3547.text:
his own and others came as dower slaves from
Martha's family. So they were important to

3558.text:
building his wealth. The standard at the time
was to think of them, okay, they're free

3564.text:
labor. Isn't it beer just to have slaves and
have free labor instead of having to pay

3571.text:
people to work? It's a money saving device,
you know, that's very simplistic.

3577.text:
Washington looked at it -- eventually -- he
believed that at first and for quite a

3580.text:
while. Eventually he looked at it as something
in the long term you saw that, why are

3587.text:
these enslaved people not working the best
they can? And we know now they were

3593.text:
resisting constantly. Every little moment
they pushed back it was an act of resistance.

3598.text:
He thought, why should they work? Why should
they want to work? They're always going

3603.text:
to do the least possible, and you can never
really achieve everything that you want to

3608.text:
achieve if that is the basis of your motivation.
So he tried to think over the long

3615.text:
term. So that's a very brief answer to your
question. Yes, sir?

3619.text:
>> A couple of questions. First, you alluded
to the tension between Mary Ball

3624.text:
and George later in life. Now, Mary Ball was,
as I understand, a notorious Tory during

3630.text:
the revolution. What was up with that and
how did they resolve that or did they resolve

3635.text:
that tension between them? And the other one
following up on the slavery question, some

3639.text:
authors accredited Lafayette, with really
inspiring Washington to rethink the whole

3647.text:
question, the whole issue of slavery and morality
and so forth and the spiritual

3651.text:
enlightenment. Do you think that played a
major factor or just a side line?

3655.text:
>> Edward Lengel: So the first question with
Mary Ball, their tension began

3660.text:
early. She was always stopping him from doing
the things he really wanted to do, to

3666.text:
look at it simply. He wants to go the sea
and she says no. She got mad when he went

3671.text:
to
the French and Indian War and he had to excuse

3674.text:
it constantly every time he went back.
Because she felt he should be focused on what

3679.text:
is important, his estate and building and
growing.

3683.text:
So they were very tense already well before
the war in the 1760s. She was

3687.text:
not welcome at Mount Vernon very much. I suspect
Martha and Mary didn't along too well,

3695.text:
but during the Revolutionary War, she did
the worst possible thing that she could do

3703.text:
for
him, which was to appeal to the Virginia Assembly

3707.text:
for support, financial support,
implying that George was not giving her what

3712.text:
she needed to get by, and that was -- that
just infuriated him, because it was a public

3718.text:
humiliation.
So they never really reconciled.

3722.text:
Now, on the slavery question, yes, Lafayette,
also men like John Lawrence, his

3728.text:
aide from South Carolina, John and Emory Lawrence,
two great people, South Carolinians

3734.text:
who argued against slavery. Yes, they played
a role, but I think for Washington, if you

3740.text:
look at what held him back, he was a law and
order guy. And he feared -- I'm just being

3749.text:
very forth right. He was afraid of what would
happen if you let these people free, that

3756.text:
the ideal was there, the understanding of
the economic principle was there. You let

3762.text:
these people free, anything can happen. And

3769.text:
>> A comment and question. The comment is
I seem to recall reading at one

3774.text:
point that George Washington wrote to his
-- the overseers that whenever possible they

3783.text:
were to reward good work by the kind of thing
that appealed to that particular slave,

3790.text:
that it might be a shirt, an extra shirt for
one person. It might be being excused

3796.text:
early, to be able to go home and visit the
family on the other farm, or something, sort

3802.text:
of motivation, incentive. That's my comment.
Which I would be interested in what you

3809.text:
have to say on that. The question that has
been in my mind for a long time is that one

3814.text:
of the biggest mistakes that I think that
he made in his life was putting into his will

3820.text:
the fact that around 100 people were going
to be freed when that lady died, and the idea

3828.text:
that she would be safe under those circumstances
doesn't sound to me like anything that

3834.text:
he thought through.
>> Edward Lengel: Martha would agree with

3837.text:
you completely.
So, yes, he did try to find other ways to

3843.text:
motivate them. He also provided
very well for his body servant, William Moore,

3852.text:
Billy, Lee, who stayed with him
constantly throughout the war and George provided

3857.text:
for him financially for the remainder
of his life. On the other hand, and you just

3863.text:
have to say, this is reality. There's a
very, very unpleasant letter, if you go to

3870.text:
the Washington Papers blog, it's called
Washington's Quill, one of my colleagues wrote

3875.text:
a blog on this. In 1790s farm manager
Anthony Whiting writes to George and says,

3883.text:
I'm just very upset with this slave, I think
her name was Charlotte. She's not doing what

3888.text:
I tell her to do and resisting constantly,
and he whipped her. He thrashed her, flogged

3896.text:
her. And George writes back to him saying,
I approve.

3901.text:
Now, he didn't so far as I know, George did
not order this to be done himself,

3911.text:
but just that fact that his farm manager did
it and he said, I approve, there's no

3918.text:
excuse for that. I can't excuse it. That doesn't
mean I believe Washington was an evil

3924.text:
or bad man, but he was a human being, and
he had a lapse, pretty serious lapse there.

3931.text:
So he was torn with slavery. Slavery was one
of the great moral quandaries of

3939.text:
his life and he did not often respond. He
often did not respond the way he should have.

3946.text:
>> He appointed his second cousin, Washington's
caretaker at Mount Vernon

3950.text:
during the revolutionary and I was wondering
the same or different was the practice as

3956.text:
his cousin George.
>> Edward Lengel: That's a good question.

3960.text:
And Lund's task was to maintain
the estate and to keep it from falling apart.

3968.text:
And there's some interesting
correspondence. You know, the currency was

3972.text:
becoming worthless during the war. The
patriotic thing to do was keep using the currency.

3978.text:
The less you use the paper currency,
the more worthless it become. George is leading

3983.text:
the continental army, he should use
this currency even if it means his own ruin.

3989.text:
He writes and says, there's nothing we can
do about it, get rid of your currency and

3995.text:
buy land. That's one of the thing that Lund
does. He uses every bit of currency he can

4001.text:
find to buy land.
Also trades in slave people to buy land and

4010.text:
other commodities because he
believes that's the safe thing to do. He maintains

4014.text:
the estate and keeps it from
completely falling apart, but when George

4018.text:
gets home he's pretty disappointed because
the

4021.text:
building is dilapidated. It's livable but
it's not really in very good shape. I think

4028.text:
if Martha had stayed home she would have done
a much better job with it, but she was

4032.text:
with George all the time in the camp, or most
of the time she spent with him. And

4040.text:
Lund's worst mistake is when the British -- I
think 1781, a British warship sails up the

4047.text:
Potomac and weighs anchor right off Mount
Vernon and he's terrified they're going to

4053.text:
come and burn the estate. He bribes the British
and sends out all these commodities

4059.text:
like roast chicken and all types of other
stuff to make the British happy and hams and

4066.text:
stuff like that. Please don't burn Mount Vernon,
I'll give you anything you want. And

4071.text:
they don't burn Mount Vernon and they eat
chicken and sail off. When George hears about

4076.text:
this he's apoplectic and would rather Mount
Vernon had been burned than the British

4084.text:
bribe not to burn it. So one had to eat humble
pie for a long time for that.
